questions.text: A young adult presented with diminished vision. On examination, he has anterior uveitis, vitritis, focal necrotising granuloma and a macular spot. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The word for clinching the diagnosis is FOCAL. The presence of a focal necrotising retinitis with granuloma in the setting of vitritis and anterior chamber inflammation is pathognomonic for ocular toxoplasmosis.

Toxoplasma gondii invades retinal tissue, causing localised necrosis and granuloma formation. The overlying vitreous haze produces the classic "headlight in fog" appearance.

Prompt recognition directs treatment with anti-parasitic therapy (pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine) and adjunctive corticosteroids to control inflammation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Proteus syndrome (Option A): A genetic hamartomatous disorder without focal retinal necrosis or vitritis.

White dot syndromes (Option B) are a spectrum of multifocal chorioretinal inflammatory disorders, such as Acute Posterior Multifocal Placoid Pigment Epitheliopathy (APMPPE), Multiple evanescent white dot syndrome (MEWDS), Punctate inner choroidopathy (PIC), and birdshot retinochoroidopathy, characterised by multiple discrete white lesions rather than a single focal necrotising focus.

Multifocal choroiditis (Option C) features multiple choroidal lesions without true necrotising granulomas or anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with known pulmonary sarcoidosis presents for ophthalmic evaluation. Fundus examination reveals perivenous yellow-white exudates along retinal veins resembling "candle wax drippings." Which condition is this finding most characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Perivenous exudates ("candle wax drippings") represent nodular or segmental periphlebitis and are pathognomonic for severe ocular sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease of unknown aetiology characterised by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. The disease most commonly affects the skin, lungs, lymph nodes and eyes, but can affect virtually any organ.

The International Workshop on Ocular Sarcoidosis (IWOS), reporting in 2009, identified seven key signs in the diagnosis of intraocular sarcoidosis:

  • Mutton fat keratic precipitates(KPs) and/or small granulomatous KPs and/or iris nodules(Koeppe and/or Busacca).
  • Trabecular meshwork(TM) nodulesand/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae.
  • Vitreous opacities: snowballs and/or strings of pearls
  • Multiple chorioretinal peripheral lesions(active and/or atrophic) - Multiple small pale-yellow infiltrates, sometimes with a punched-out appearance, are the commonest; they are often most numerous inferiorly.
  • Nodular and/or segmental periphlebitis (± candle wax drippings) and/or retinal macroaneurysm in an inflamed eye.
    • Periphlebitisappears as yellowish or grey-white perivenous sheathing.
    • Perivenous exudatesreferred to as 'candle wax drippings'(en taches de bougie) are typical of severe sarcoid periphlebitis.
  • Optic disc nodule(s)/granuloma(s) and/or solitary choroidal nodule.
  • Bilaterality.

Explanation of Other Options:

Behcet's syndrome (Option A) causes occlusive vasculitis and retinal haemorrhages but lacks the granulomatous perivenous exudates seen in sarcoidosis.

Tubercular uveitis (Option B) may cause choroiditis and granulomas but typically produces segmental choroidal lesions rather than perivenous sheathing.

Traumatic uveitis (Option C) results from mechanical injury, does not produce organised periphlebitis or candle wax drippings.

choices.text: A history of visceral larva migrans is always present
Examination of the patient's stool is useful in diagnosing the disease
Bilateral ocular involvement should make one doubt the accuracy of the diagnosis
Ultrasound of the granuloma typically shows calcification

questions.text: In ocular toxocariasis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bilateral ocular involvement is exceedingly rare in toxocariasis, which typically presents as a unilateral granulomatous retinochoroiditis from larval invasion of a single eye.

Humans are aberrant hosts with a low parasitic load, and larvae usually migrate to one globe, producing vitritis and a solitary peripheral granuloma.

Prompt recognition of the unilateral pattern guides serologic testing (ELISA for Toxocara antibodies) and avoids unnecessary systemic investigations.

Ocular toxocariasis/ocular larva migrans generally occurs independently of visceral larva migrans and is associated with a lower parasitic load. (Option A)

The worm does not complete its life cycle in humans. So, eggs are not shed in the stool. The life cycle is completed in dogs or cats. (Option B)

Toxocaral granulomas are non-calcified and appear as solid inflammatory masses on ultrasound. (Option D)

questions.text: Headlight in fog appearance is characteristic for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The headlight in fog appearance is characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

Ocular manifestations of toxoplasmosis:

  • Toxoplasma gondii is the leading protozoan responsible for posterior uveitis
  • Symptoms - Unilateral acute or subacute onset of floaters, blurring and photophobia.
  • Spill-over anterior uveitisis common.
  • A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar(satellite lesion) is typical. Lesions tend to involve the posterior pole.
  • De novo foci not associated with an old scar, and multiple lesions - occur more frequently in the immunocompromised.
  • Vitritismay be severe and impair fundus visualisation. Headlight in the fog is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through vitritis.
  • Vasculitisis more commonly venous.
  • Optic disc oedemais common.
  • Accompanying a nearby or adjacent pigmented retinochoroidal scar.
  • Extensive and fulminant retinal involvement is generally confined to the immunocompromised.
  • Neuroretinitis similar to that seen in cat-scratch disease, is rare and may be a marker of acutely acquired rather than reactivated infection.
  • Visual loss- Causes of permanently reduced vision(around 25% of eyes) include macular inflammatory lesions and oedema, optic nerve involvement, vascular occlusion, serous, rhegmatogenous and tractional retinal detachment and late secondary choroidal neovascularisation.
  • Healingin immunocompetent hosts usually occurs spontaneously within 6-8 weeks, although vitreous opacities take longer to clear.
  • Recurrencesare seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a serious bilateral granulomatous (non-suppurative) panuveitis that follows a penetrating ocular trauma.

The injured eye is called the exciting eye, and the fellow eye, which also develops uveitis is called the sympathising eye.

Very rarely, sympathetic ophthalmitis can also occur following an intraocular surgery.

Pathology:

  • The primary inflammatory mediators are thought to be T cells (the initial wave of infiltrative cells is composed of CD4+ helper T cells and a later wave of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells) that invade the uveal tract.
  • The inflammation is usually granulomatous, and the choroid is diffusely thickened with lymphocytes, nests of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells. The epithelioid cells and giant cells often contain melanin pigment.
  • The inflammatory process does not usually involve the choriocapillaris (in contrast to Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome) or the retina.
  • Dalen-Fuchs nodules, which are clusters of epithelioid cells containing pigment, lying between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane, are also seen.
  • Anteriorly, the iris can appear thickened with nodular infiltrations.

Dalen Fuchs nodules

questions.text: What is Jensen's choroiditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Jensen's choroiditis, also called juxtapapillary choroiditis, manifests as an oval exudative lesion immediately adjacent to the optic disc, most often in young patients, and commonly produces a sector-shaped visual field defect.

Choroiditis is usually classified according to the number and location of the areas involved.

Disseminated or diffuse choroiditis: (Option C)

  • It is diagnosed when small areas of inflammationare scattered over a greater part of the fundus behind the equator.

Multifocal choroiditis:

  • It has fewer and more discrete foci.
  • It is frequently symptomlessand discovered only on routine examination.

Central choroiditis: (Option A)

  • This affects the posterior pole or macular region.
  • It may occur as part of disseminated choroiditis or can occur alone.

Juxtapapillary choroiditis (of Jensen):

  • Usually ovalin shape, this type occurs in young persons as an exudation close to and about the same size as the disc.
  • There is generally a sector-shaped defectin the field of vision.
  • The inflammation slowly subsides, leaving a patch of atrophy, but recurrencemay take place.

questions.text: Penetrating injury to which ocular structure is most likely to precipitate sympathetic ophthalmia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Penetrating trauma to the ciliary body can lead to the development of bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, known as sympathetic ophthalmia. Hence known as a danger area of the eye.

Sympathetic Opthalmitis:

  • Uveal melanocyte antigens in the ciliary body are normally sequestered from immune surveillance. Injury exposes these antigens, triggering a T-cell-mediated autoimmune response (initial CD44 infiltration followed by CD8‚Å∫ cytotoxic cells) against both the injured ("exciting") and fellow ("sympathising") eye.
  • Clinical features of sympathetic ophthalmia:
    • Exciting eye: history of trauma or surgery, redness, pain.
    • Sympathising eye: develops blurred vision, photophobia, loss of accommodation, and granulomatous anterior uveitis weeks to years later.
    • Fundus shows multifocal choroidal infiltrates, nodular periphlebitis, and occasionally exudative retinal detachment.
  • Treatment principles: Emergency enucleation of a blind exciting eye within two weeks can prevent or lessen sympathetic involvement; high-dose systemic corticosteroids (tapered over months) and steroid-sparing immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine, cyclosporine) are mainstays for the sympathising eye.

Explanation of Other Options:

Optic nerve (Option A): Injury here does not release uveal antigens, so it does not trigger sympathetic ophthalmia.

Sclera (Option C): The sclera lacks sequestered uveal antigens, and penetration rarely leads to bilateral panuveitis.

Retina (Option D): Retinal injury alone does not expose ciliary body antigens responsible for sympathetic ophthalmia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Birdshot Chorioretinopathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Birdshot chorioretinopathy is an uncommon, idiopathic, chronic posterior uveitis that always affects both eyes (bilateral), predominantly in middle-aged women.

Over 95% patients are positive for HLA A29. The disease involves both the retina and choroid independently.

Clinical Features

  • Insidious Visual Loss: Gradual central vision impairment, photopsia, and floaters without pain or redness.
  • Vitritis: Prominent vitreous haze ("vitreous floaters") distinguishes it from other white-dot syndromes.

Fundus Findings

  • Active Lesions: Multiple ill-defined, ovoid cream-coloured choroidal spots (<1 disc diameter), often radiating from the optic disc but sparing the fovea.
  • Inactive Lesions: Well-delineated atrophic spots indicating prior disease activity.
  • Complications: Cystoid macular oedema, epiretinal membrane formation, and choroidal neovascularisation may develop.

Treatment:

  • Systemic/Periocular Corticosteroids to control active inflammation.
  • Immunosuppressive Agents (methotrexate, cyclosporine) or Biologics (infliximab, adalimumab) for long-term disease control and steroid-sparing.
  • Cream coloured "birdshot" lesions

choices.text: Serologic testing for herpes virus, including CMV
Blood culture for herpes virus, including CMV

questions.text: An individual infected with HIV has a necrotizing retinitis on fundus examination. Which of the following will be most helpful to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infection is the most likely cause of necrotising retinitis in an HIV patient. The most common causes in an HIV patient could be viral (CMV, HSV/VZV) or parasitic (Toxoplasmosis). Vitreous biopsy provides direct sampling of intraocular fluid, allowing microscopic, culture, or PCR-based identification of the specific pathogen causing necrotising retinitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Serologic testing for herpes viruses (Option A) reflects systemic antibody levels but cannot confirm active intraocular infection or distinguish among viral and parasitic causes.

Mantoux test (Option B) is unreliable in HIV due to anergy and has no role in diagnosing necrotising retinitis.

Blood culture for herpes viruses (Option D) has poor sensitivity for ocular disease and does not correlate with intraocular viral load.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient has an uneventful phacoemulsification with IOL implantation. He presented with pain, diminution of vision, redness, watering and a greyish yellow pupillary reflex on the third postoperative day. Examination revealed circumcorneal congestion, aqueous cells 4+, hypopyon in the anterior chamber with posterior synechiae and retrolental flare. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Painful red eye with diminution of vision along with evidence of aqueous flare, hypopyon and loss of normal red reflex, three days after cataract surgery, suggests a diagnosis of acute postoperative endophthalmitis.

Vitreous becomes purulent as shown by a yellow reflex with oblique illumination.

Intraocular inoculation of bacteria or fungi during surgery leads to rapid inflammation of the vitreous and aqueous, producing pus and the characteristic appearance.

Acute postoperative endophthalmitis generally develops within 2-5 days of surgery and has a fulminant course.

Explanation of Other Options:

Keratitis (Option A): Corneal infection causes focal corneal infiltrates, epithelial defect, and marked photophobia, but does not produce hypopyon or a purulent pupillary reflex.

Glaucoma (Option B): Presents with elevated IOP, corneal edema, and mid-dilated pupil; pain and redness occur, but hypopyon and retrolental flare are absent.

Postoperative cyclitis (Option D): Mild anterior segment inflammation without vitreous involvement; would show limited cells/flare and no hypopyon or yellow pupillary reflex.

questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient develops progressive visual loss and dense vitritis. Fundus exam shows fluffy white chorioretinal deposits, and vitreous culture grows Candida species. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Treatment of Candida endophthalmitis includes:

Antifungal treatment: The Agent is decided based on culture sensitivity.

  • Intravenous amphotericin-B in combination with oral flucytosineis given, but resistance is a concern. (Option B)
  • Voriconazoleorally or intravenously has a broad spectrum of antifungal action with low reported resistance and high ocular penetration; adjunctive intravitreal treatment may be given(100 µg in 0.1 ml), with serial injections probably needed. (Option A)

Pars plana vitrectomy (Option D) should be considered at an early stage, especially for severe or unresponsive disease. Along with providing a substantial culture specimen, it reduces fungal and antigen load, facilitates therapeutic agent penetration and clears the ocular media.

questions.text:
A vitreous aspirate from a case of endophthalmitis on culture yields Gram-positive round to oval cells, 12-14 Armstrong in size. The aspirate on Gram staining shows the presence of pseudohyphae.
Which of the following is the most common etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Candida albicans is the most common cause of endogenous fungal endophthalmitis, and it appears as budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae on Gram stain; lesions progress slowly with fluffy "cotton-ball" vitreal colonies.

It can present as:

  • Chorioretinitis- Bilateral, multiple, small(<1mm) well-circumscribed lesions with post-equatorial vitritis.
  • Vitritis - Presents with fluffy 'cotton ball' or 'string of pearls' colonies

Histologically, budding yeasts with characteristic pseudohyphae pattern seen.

Progression is typically much slower than bacterial endophthalmitis.

Bilateral involvement is common.

Culture or PCR of vitreous samples confirming yeast morphology is essential for targeted antifungal therapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspergillus (Option A): filamentous fungus with septate hyphae branching at acute angles; not seen as round budding yeasts in endogenous endophthalmitis.

Rhizopus (Option B): A Mucorales species with broad, nonseptate hyphae; typically causes rhinocerebral disease and rarely endogenous ocular infection.

Fusarium (Option D): Hyaline filamentous fungus with septate hyphae; usually associated with traumatic or contact lens-related keratitis rather than endogenous vitritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as a local injection for ophthalmic use?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the following are examples of steroids.

Methylprednisolone is administered only systemically.

The remaining steroids can be administered locally or systemically.

Explanation of Other Options:

Triamcinolone (Option A): Widely used intravitreally (IVTA) or via sub-Tenon's injection to treat uveitic macular oedema and posterior segment inflammation.

Prednisolone (Option B): Available for periocular (sub-Tenon's) injection and intracameral use to control both anterior and posterior segment inflammation.

Dexamethasone (Option D): Delivered locally via intravitreal implants (e.g., dexamethasone intravitreal implant) or subconjunctival injections for sustained anti-inflammatory effect.

questions.text: Chronic use of systemic steroids most commonly leads to which ocular complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior subcapsular cataract is the hallmark ocular side effect of long-term systemic corticosteroid therapy, resulting from disruption of lens epithelial cell metabolism and protein aggregation.

Chronic systemic steroids also predispose to delayed wound healing, increased risk of ocular infections, papilledema, and central retinal vein occlusion, but cataract formation remains the most frequent.

Steroid-induced glaucoma is more often associated with topical or periocular administration rather than systemic use.

Injudicious use of systemic steroids leads to the following ocular complications:

  • Cataract - most common
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Infections of the eye
  • Papilloedema
  • Central retinal vein occlusion
  • Glaucoma - more often associated with topical ocular or periocular steroids

Explanation of Other Options:

Glaucoma (Option B) is primarily linked to topical or periocular steroids; systemic steroids elevate IOP far less commonly.

Uveitis (Option C) corticosteroids are anti-inflammatory and used to treat uveitis, not cause it.

Conjunctival and lid papillomatosis (Option D) papillomatous changes are unrelated to steroid therapy.

questions.text: The drug used in Luminate programme for non-infectious uveitis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Voclosporinis a next-generation calcineurin inhibitor developed to more potently and predictably suppress T-cell activation.
  • The LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) clinical development program was initiated in 2007 to assess the safety and efficacy of voclosporin for the treatment, maintenance, and control of all forms of non-infectious uveitis.
  • By binding cyclophilin and inhibiting calcineurin, voclosporin prevents interleukin-2 transcription and downstream inflammatory cascades within the uveal tract.

Explanation of Other Options:

Methotrexate (Option B): A folate-antagonist immunosuppressant used off-label for chronic uveitis but not studied in the LUMINATE calcineurin inhibitor trials.

Infliximab (Option C): A TNF-α inhibitor reserved for refractory or systemic-associated uveitis; it was not part of the voclosporin LUMINATE programme.

Cyclosporine (Option D): The first-generation calcineurin inhibitor in uveitis therapy; LUMINATE specifically tested its next-generation analogue, voclosporin, for improved potency and safety.

questions.text: What is the mainstay of treatment for uveitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Steroids are the cornerstone of uveitis management, suppressing intraocular inflammation by inhibiting leukocyte migration and cytokine release.
  • Cycloplegics (e.g., atropine) relieve ciliary muscle spasm, reduce pain, stabilise the blood-aqueous barrier, and prevent posterior synechiae formation.
  • The combination addresses both the underlying immune-mediated inflammation and its symptomatic sequelae, improving visual prognosis and minimising complications.

questions.text: Persistent pupillary membrane originates from
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent pupillary membranes are remnants of the tunica vasculosa lentis vessels that normally regress. They arise at the iris collarette, the thickest embryologic vascular zone encircling the pupil.

During fetal life, a vascular network supplies the developing lens, and regression begins centrally at the collarette and progresses outward, leaving fine mesh remnants if involution is incomplete.

PPMs are the most common iris anomaly, usually asymptomatic, thin strands crossing the pupil that rarely affect vision unless dense or attached to the lens.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of choroidal neurovascularization?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of Choroidal neovascularisation.

Choroidal neovascularisation (CNV) consists of a blood vessel complex that extends through Bruch's membrane from the choriocapillaris into the subretinal pigment epithelium (type 1) or subretinal space (type 2).

Causes of choroid neovascularisation (CNV):

  • Degenerative conditions- Age-related macular degeneration, myopia, angioid streaks.
  • Inflammatory or infectious conditions- Histoplasmosis, sarcoidosis, multifocal choroiditis
  • Choroidal tumors
  • Choroidal rupture
  • Laser photocoagulation
  • Idiopathic

Although high myopia (Option C) and angioid streaks (Option B) also disrupt Bruch's membrane and predispose to CNV, their overall incidence is far lower than that of AMD.

Hypermetropia (Option D) does not cause CNV.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for evisceration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Malignancy (retinoblastoma) needs to be enucleated, as the most common route of spread is directly through the optic nerve and sclera and in evisceration sclera is not removed.

Contraindications for evisceration include:

  • Known or suspected intraocular malignancy. A preoperative ocular ultrasound is mandatory to rule out occult malignancy.
  • Phthisis bulbi, microphthalmia, scleral contracture (relative) - evisceration may be more difficult due to a lack of sufficient scleral shell volume to adequately encase the implant.
  • Evisceration surgery in a recently injured eyecarries a definite small risk of sympathetic ophthalmia in the apposing eye, because some uveal tissue is always left behind in the scleral canals.

Explanation of Other Options:

Endophthalmitis (Option B): In severe, refractory endophthalmitis, evisceration removes the infected vitreous and uveal tissue to control infection and pain.

Severe globe trauma (Option C): When the eye is irreparably damaged, evisceration salvages orbital volume and allows prosthesis placement.

Expulsive haemorrhage (Option D): Rapid intraocular bleeding with prolapse often necessitates evisceration to manage pain and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from gyrate atrophy of the choroid, which is due to the deficiency of the enzyme Ornithine aminotransferase. Which of the following is beneficial for the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ornithine aminotransferase deficiency (also known as gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina) is an inborn error of ornithine metabolism, caused by decreased activity of the enzyme ornithine aminotransferase. Biochemically, it can be detected by elevated levels of ornithine in the blood.

Clinically, it presents initially with poor night vision, which slowly progresses to total blindness. It is believed to be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

Research suggests there can be some adverse effects on muscles and the brain. The cause of this is somewhat unclear but may relate to very low levels of creatine, often found in this population.

Treatment may include Vitamin B6, lysine or a dramatic dietary change to minimise arginine from the patient's diet. Hence, all of the mentioned options are correct.

questions.text: Pseudouveitis is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A necrotising malignant melanoma may present with masquerade syndrome, in which tumour presents with inflammatory signs, which are mistaken to be a case of endogenous uveitis, and thus, pseudouveitis.

Other causes include:

  • Acute leukemia
  • Juvenile xanthogranuloma
  • Lymphoma
  • Anterior segment ischemia

Explanation of Other Options:

Toxoplasmosis (Option A) presents with focal necrotising retinitis and "headlight in fog" vitritis, attributable to infection rather than tumour necrosis.

Retinoblastoma (Option C) childhood intraocular malignancy with leukocoria and calcifications on imaging; rare in adults and not typical for pseudouveitis in this age group.

Sarcoidosis (Option D) causes true granulomatous uveitis with systemic signs and responds to steroids; no masquerade by tumour.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV patient started HAART three months ago; his CD4 count rose from 50 to 250 cells/mm3. He now has floaters, blurred vision, 1+ anterior chamber cells, vitritis, and cystoid macular oedema without new CMV lesions. Which HAART-associated ocular condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for immune recovery uveitis (IRU), a sterile inflammatory response that emerges as HAART restores CD44 T-cell function, provoking inflammation against residual CMV antigen in the eye.

Key features include anterior chamber cells, vitritis, macular oedema, and epiretinal membrane formation in the absence of active infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Retinitis (Option A): Would show active necrotising lesions, IRU occurs without new retinitis.

Choroiditis (Option B): Inflammation confined to the choroid is not characteristic of post-HAART immune recovery.

Keratitis (Option D): Corneal inflammation is unrelated to immune reconstitution.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of visual loss in AIDS patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CMV retinitis is the most common opportunistic ocular infection among patients with AIDS and is the most common cause of visual loss.

The disease progresses along the retinal blood vessels, causing confluent areas of retinal whitening, often associated with flame-shaped retinal haemorrhages and hard exudates. The lesions progress in a 'brushfire' manner, led by an active border and satellite lesions.

Without prompt antiviral therapy, CMV retinitis can lead to full-thickness retinal destruction, detachment, and irreversible blindness.

Explanation of Other Options:

Toxoplasmosis (Option A) causes focal necrotising retinochoroiditis but is less frequent in AIDS and presents as a single lesion rather than diffuse retinitis.

Herpetic retinitis (Option B): HSV/VZV acute retinal necrosis is rare in HIV, marked by painful peripheral lesions, not the brushfire spread of CMV.

HIV retinitis (Option D) manifests as cotton-wool spots and microvasculopathy but seldom leads to profound visual loss compared to CMV necrosis.

choices.text: Melanocytic deposits in anterior part of iris
Melanocyte proliferation in posterior uveal tissue

questions.text: Intractable secondary glaucoma is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diffuse iris melanoma infiltrates the entire iris and anterior chamber angle with malignant cells, leading to relentless neovascularization and obstruction of aqueous outflow that is unresponsive to standard glaucoma therapies (intractable).

Sheets of tumour replace normal trabecular meshwork, preventing drainage despite medical or surgical intervention.

Because the glaucoma is refractory, treatment usually necessitates enucleation to control both intraocular pressure and tumour spread.

Intractable secondary glaucoma may also occur in cases of blunt trauma due to an anteriorly dislocated lens setting caught in the pupil.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nodular iris melanoma (Option B): Localised nodules may transiently elevate IOP but typically respond to local resection or radiotherapy, resolving secondary glaucoma.

Melanocytic deposits in the anterior part of the iris (Option C): Pigment dispersion can cause pigmentary glaucoma, but this is usually controllable with medications or laser.

Melanocyte proliferation in posterior uveal tissue (Option D): Posterior uveal melanoma rarely involves the angle; any secondary glaucoma tends to be manageable rather than intractable.

questions.text: Uveal effusion syndrome may be associated with all of the following, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Uveal Effusion Syndrome (Ciliochoroidal Effusion) is an idiopathic disease of the retina and choroid characterised by abnormal accumulation of serous fluid in the outer layer of the ciliary body or choroid. Myopia, with its thinner sclera and open drainage, does not predispose to uveal effusions, making it the exception.

Clinical Features:

  • Structurally abnormal sclera (Thick Sclera) (Option C)
  • Abnormal accumulation of serous fluid in the outer layer of the ciliary body and choroid, leading to
    • Detachment of Ciliary body (Exudative)
    • Detachment of Choroid (Exudative) Deep Ciliochoroidal detachments (Option B)
    • Detachment of Retina (Exudative)
  • Absence of inflammation or neoplastic disease
  • Eyes may be nanopthalmic (small) or hypermetropic (Option D)
  • Phthisis and hypotonia are usually due to ciliary body shutdown from chronic detachment, which compromises the blood supply to the ciliary processes
  • Mottling of pigment epithelium (Leopard spots) may be seen after spontaneous resolution.

questions.text: Which among the following types of uveitis is a relative contraindication to put an intraocular lens after cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The usage of intraocular lens (IOL) for the treatment of cataracts in patients with juvenile idiopathic Arthritis(JIA) is controversial.

There is a high complication rate (cyclitic membrane formation and progression to hypotony and phthisis) following cataract surgery in patients with JIA-associated iridocycitis, due to the difficulty in controlling the more aggressive inflammatory response seen in these children.

Lensectomy and vitrectomy via the pars plana have been advocated.

The following guidelines must be followed when selecting patients with JIA for cataract surgery with IOL implants:

  • The patient's intraocular inflammationmust be well controlled for at least 3 months before surgery with systemic immunomodulatory treatment and must not require frequent instillation of topical corticosteroids.
  • Only acrylic lensesshould be implanted.
  • Patients must be followed up very frequentlyafter cataract surgery to detect any inflammation, and inflammation that occurs must be aggressively treated.
  • Immunomodulatory treatmentmust be used preoperatively and postoperatively, not just perioperatively.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with AIDS (CD4 count 25 cells/mm3) presents with progressive blurred vision and floaters in his right eye. Fundus examination reveals the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This image demonstrates CMV retinitis, characterised by a "pizza-pie" appearance - fluffy white areas of retinal necrosis ("cotton-wool") with overlying haemorrhages ("ketchup") distributed along the vascular arcades.

CMV retinitis is caused by cytomegalovirus, a double-stranded DNA virus in the herpes viridae family. It is often associated with HIV/AIDS and was extremely rare before the AIDS epidemic. It is also associated with severe immunosuppression from chemotherapy. With the advent of antiretroviral therapies, the incidence of CMV retinitis has decreased by 90% in the AIDS population.

CMV retinitis can present as:

  1. Fulminant - hemorrhagic necrosis on white/yellow cloudy retinal lesions. They may be centred around vasculature.
  2. Granular - Found more often in the retinal periphery with little to no necrosis and haemorrhage.
  3. Perivascular - The classic "frosted branch" angiitis showing white lesions surrounding the retinal vessels.

Patients present with decreased visual acuity and floaters. Some may present with flashing lights (photopsias) or blind spots (scotomata).

First-line therapy is generally oral valganciclovir, which is a pro-drug of ganciclovir. The induction dose is 900 mg twice daily for 21 days, followed by maintenance of 900 mg daily.

Explanation of Other Options:

Toxocariasis (Option B) presents with a peripheral granuloma and vitritis ("vitreous traction bands", not diffuse necrotising retinitis with haemorrhage.

Toxoplasmosis (Option C) shows a focal necrotising retinitis adjacent to an old scar and dense vitritis ("headlight in fog"), lacking widespread hemorrhagic lesions.

Ocular sarcoidosis (Option D) causes granulomatous periphlebitis ("candle-wax drippings") and multiple chorioretinal infiltrates, without the hemorrhagic brush-fire pattern.
